body:
1. I don't see anything wrong in the images you attached. (Edit: to be clear, I agree they aren't identical, however I'd hardly call the ZAP one un-readable ... my 2 cents. Maybe I'm just too used to it, or don't use it on Linux often enough.)
2. Duplicate? https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/3051

For info ZAP on Fedora looks fine to me :/
Certainly doesnt look worse than any of the other apps I use on it.

#3051 is related to the `Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings`. Without it the font rendering is abysmal. But with each possible flag options - I'm using the `gasp` - the request/response font rendering in owasp zap is still bad, this is the problem I'm writing about.

Here I've placed the comparison on one screenshot:

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4216259/25755247/7f55f68e-31c2-11e7-84e4-e69773fcf204.png)

You can see the "ideal" - system rendering (gedit in debian); slightly worse, but still ok burp; and bad zap rendering. I understand that the "system" rendering is a problem in java - the guys from jetbrains had similar (?): https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-57233
@psiinon Can you please post a screenshot of zap on fedora with request or response tab opened?
Sure - could just be me not used to poor fonts ;) http://imgur.com/mjDNqsU

Or me being choosy ;)

It looks similar, if not the same with default font:

![screenshot from 2017-05-05 19-03-30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4216259/25756168/0b022204-31c6-11e7-80fa-92b6dc131997.png)

If it is not hard to you to read it for a long time (with this rendering) I'm afraid I will not convince you. I know that I should be happy that we have a graphical interface ;) But if there is at least a slight chance of improving the font rendering - please, consider this.

Maybe if the font in the request/response window could be changed by the user it would be enough (because now only the font size is taken from the settings, font name is ignored in the source window) - maybe it's a problem visible especially with the default font? Just an idea.
I'm all for making ZAP as easy to use as possible, and that definitely includes improving font rendering and giving users extra choices (eg being able to choose fonts) :)

i have aproblem with zap font to in manjaro linux, the font is really poor , i changed it and all fonts look the same , i open it withe `zaproxy` command in the command line,  i think i opend it the worong way or something like that, any help ?
@ksdev-pl @ahmed-MAE could you try this and let us know if it addresses your issue: https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/wiki/FAQBadFonts

Hi

I'm not sure if there is anything new in the FAQ. I am already using the:
`_JAVA_OPTIONS='-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=gasp'`
in /etc/environment (the effect is visible on the screenshots).

I've tested the options from the FAQ (I've changed the `JAVA_FONTS` path because there is no "TTF" folder in Kali):
```
_JAVA_OPTIONS='-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=on'
JAVA_OPTIONS='-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=on'
JAVA_FONTS=/usr/share/fonts/truetype
```
I've also tried to run the zap from the command line.

There is no difference in font rendering. That is: the font looks like with the: `_JAVA_OPTIONS='-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=gasp'` option that I already used. I don't think that additional options are necessary, it's possible that it's the only option needed.

The problem on the screenshot in #3051 looks like missing `_JAVA_OPTIONS='-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=gasp'` - without this the font rendering is certainly worse.

The problem I've written about is related to the source/request/response code window - please compare the request/response font with the interface font (on the screenshot). With `_JAVA_OPTIONS='-Dawt.useSystemAAFontSettings=gasp'` the font in the interface is quite OK, but the font in the request/response window is still "bad", as shown in the attached comparison between the zap/burp/system font rendering.
@ksdev-pl is the setting (context menu) View > Anti-Aliasing enabled in the Request/Response tabs? And changing the setting makes any difference?

Yes, anti-aliasing is enabled, I've tried this option already - it works correctly, so disabling it makes the font not anti-aliased (worse).

The screenshot shows the font with anti-aliasing enabled on Kali.

OK, that component is not using the font selected in the options (like other components do), we can easily change that.

When no font is selected in the options, should that component use the system/Java default font or still allow the component to use its own font (like now, which tends to be monospaced)?

issue.title: Use selected font in Request/Response panels

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Change HttpPanelSyntaxHighlightTextArea to use the font selected in the
options or use default font of the component (e.g. monospaced).
Change FontUtils to allow to check if a custom font was set.

Fix #3490 - Poor font rendering on linux

body:
The option to change the font in the request/response panel (or if the panel would use the font selected in the current options) would be great and should help.

I'm not sure about the answer to the question. If there will be an option to change the font it's not so important; even if it will look like now when no custom font is selected it will be easily changeable.

The default one for the request/response panel is monospaced (?), and the interface font is not, so it's an argument to keep the monospaced as default.
